page.title: 13Richmond Park 2.White Lodge
page.content: White Lodge, perched on a hillock near the middle of Richmond Park, has been called "a small architectural treasure - a miniature palazzo with Palladian portico and spacious garden." It was built in 1729 as a hunting lodge for George 1 and enlarged for later Sovereigns. It still belongs to the Crown. Queen Victoria and Prince Albert were in residence there from time to time; the Duke of Windsor was born there and finally King George 6th and Queen Elizabeth lived there as Duke and Duchess of York. In 1955 the Royal Ballet School aquired it as a Junior Boarding School, to replace the day school at Barons Court. Now the children aged 11-16 were put in this villa, most of them as boarders. As well as intensive ballet training they receive general education up to "O" level examinations. (continued over)
